review_title: Executives should Value their Support Staff
pros:
Independent work and project, no micromanaging
Whatever supplies you need you can probably find in storage or put in a request and if its reasonable, it has a good chance of being approved.
cons:
Lack of shared help b/c ppl tend to get siloed into their own jobs by their upper hierarchy. 
Don't get credit for helping co-worker by providing expertise, time or effort, in fact, its almost like it takes you away from your job so don't help them, concentrate on your own duties
projects get done and even if they have a cost-savings they are overlooked for more vocal employees that don't do as much, but then they get recognized at the end of the year
pay disparity exists and is not recognized

cons: Overall, like most universities, UH has been run into the red over the last 20 years. Management has not handled the books well, and COVID has just made things worse.

Make your own curriculum

pros: Fusion and country lifestyle, good benefit,

pros: Pros: state job with pensionCons: it is a typical state union job
cons:
IT (Former Employee), Manoa – November 6, 2013

Think twice before accepting a job here. You will see lot of old timers close to their retirement age waiting for their pension. UH relies on old and obsolete technology. It is a state union job so it is all about seniority and not performance or your skill set. You will find lots of old timers who lack the skills still on the job. Once on board, you will be tasked with responsibilities the senior staff don't want to perform. You will receive state employee benefits which isn't much. You pay half of the medical insurance costs and union dues without choice. If you are looking for a job that will pay your bills and medical until you find a better one then perhaps this place is good for you. UH has 3 year probation period so within the 3 years they can use you and have you do all the grunt work and later decide to relieve you.

review_title: The Byzantine bureaucracy and permissive culture of passive aggressiveness and petty personal politics is worse here.
pros: Very good quality of life possible due to generally non-competitive work environment (minimal publish or perish expectation). Mostly cordial colleagues.  Good students, who need encouragement to remain in college as they struggle financially with a full course load and part-time, sometimes full-time jobs.
cons: Gaping generational (in some cases two generations) divide in most academic departments cause intellectual, programmatic and curricular rifts difficult to bridge.  Adversarial administration more intent on maintaining the status quo dating back to the 1970s instead of investing effort and vision for growth and contemporaneous university governance.  Doesn't help that some administrators are interim (many exceeding several years).

review_title: Needs better leadership and public support
pros: Most colleagues are dedicated and are trying their best. Friendly and helpful culture. Many great students with good work ethic and dedication. Culture supports work-life balance and family life. Many problems with leadership and bureaucracy, but many do feel that things are getting better. Many talented and dedicated faculty.
cons: Mysterious bureaucracy that leads to inexplicable delays. Lack of transparency and accountability. Very poor compensation in comparison to peer institutions and given extremely high cost of living. Embarassing facilities. Lack of public support for the university outside of athletics. Siege mentality of many faculty and staff.

pros: Guaranteed 4% salary raises about 2x's a year.  Plus, you get a lot of holidays off.  For the most part, people are friendly.  But the office I worked in, everyone was there based on who they knew, not what. So there were a lot of unqualified people doing jobs they had no experience in, which, I think, is part of the reason it takes so long to do anything-- processing paperwork, helping students, updating facilities, etc.
cons: No accountability. People push papers to make it appear they are working, so everything moves extremely slooooww in the entire system.  Pople are happy to just move up the 'steps' with senority, but not learn new skills.

pros:
-The pay is great depending on what you apply for as a student. The more confidential something is, the more pay you get.
-They're very lenient on the house because it's all students and all students have homework and class. It's also great that you can ask to leave early because maybe some unexpected project came up.
-Great for students looking to get some office experience
cons:
-The higher people seem to be too slow and everything seems to be taken advantage of. Some staff members leave the office when its busy and leave the student workers to deal with the craziness when we obviously need them there.
-You're delayed a month of pay in the beginning.

review_title: University of Hawaii (Manoa campus) - a neutral place to work
pros: Overall, the people at the University of Hawaii, Manoa are fine to work with.  I've worked with faculty members outside of my own department who are collaborative and committed to their research and teaching.  There are a few gems out there.
cons: There is a strong distinction between "administration" and "faculty", with administrative personnel expecting everyone around them to kowtow, and for the most part faculty and staff do so.  This experience is quite different from my experience in private industry which was much more collaborative and egalitarian.

job_title: Assistant Director, First Year Composition Center in Honolulu, HI
pros: I went back to school as an "adult student" to get a long-delayed degree, and found all my coursework to be quite stimulating, and the professors very eager to teach, and very knowledgeable. My experiences working with  the English Department as Assistant Director of the Composition Center, and with the Geology Department in one of the labs, were very fulfilling.
cons: I think about the only major drawback to the system is the relatively meager state funding. The Art Department and English Departments were both targeted, and courses were cut due to "budget concerns" while the Athletics Department grabbed a larger and larger share of tuition for their programs. I do not think that a research facility of this calibre should suffer in order to support college athletics.

pros:
Free Housing, Free meal plan
Great connections. Fantastic staff employees. 
Good management, 
Flexible hours, Resume booster. Lifelong friends and connections 
Great place to live. 5 minutes from beach and 15 minutes from downtown
cons:
Constantly on call. 
Wage is 0.48 cents an hour 
Constant partying. 
Housing only provides 1-ply toilet paper.
Get paid less than the 10 year olds making the next iPhone in China.
Do not provide training for Chinese.
This is a con because I cannot negotiate my contract with the Chinese government.
Constantly cleaning up throw up and blood. 
No A/C in the work environment. 
Constantly killing cockroaches in your provided room.
Constantly training cockroaches in your provided room to kill other cockroaches.
Cockroach battles can get violent.

review_title: Strong union, weak management, good benefits
pros: In the spirit of "ohana," everyone is friendly and courteous.  It is deep rooted with strong island relationships and it helps to learn some of the local phases such as "talk story."
cons: There are a lot of people that have been working in the same position for over 20 and 30 years. There is a strong union that protects these people, even if they do very little at work. It can be frustrating if you are the type of person that expects results quickly.

pros: The ppl are very nice here. Campus is Very beautiful, especially the trees. bus is convenient to and from the campus and it is free with Id. Dining option on campus is great, lots of Asian food.
cons: buildings are ugly. Parking is expensive and far from school buildings. Library has poor access to some key journals for research. Gym is small, swimming pool opens to public for very short time per day. Administration is inefficient

pros: Friendly co-workers, excellent management, personal growth, leadership opportunities, flexible hours. My personal experience was overall very good; I would definitely recommend for an on-campus job.
cons: Working with peers, training could be improved, student management needs more balance. Personally, I felt the most difficult aspect of this job was working as an authoritative figure over people the same age as or older than me. It was a challenge, but the end result is worth it.

review_title: All the bureaucracy, none of the pay
pros: It's better than paying tuition to go to a sh***y school
cons: Underpaid, even if we only worked 20 hours, which is what we're salaried for.  Sometimes, it's more like 40, but if you complain, you'll probably lose your job.

pros: Despite budget deficits and all of the problems that usually come with being a state school, the atmosphere was friendly and laid back, supportive and encouraging. And definitely better paid than most businesses in the area.
cons: A lot of red tape, which comes with any sort of government funded employer. Sometimes too much catering to the customer and not enough standing up for the principles of the university.

pros: Staff are friendly and cooperative.  Brand new IT building provides excellent facilities and leadership is very responsive to needs. Nice, quiet, clean and air conditioned.  Very good work life balance.
cons: The biggest drawback compared to private sector is the pay, however with the time off and benefits the overall package is competitive - but you will probably be making your lunch at home and bringing it, like most folks.  It is also difficult to advance your career since the company doesn't "grow" like a private company would.

review_title: If you want to get something done do it yourself.
pros: The students are fun although fairly lacking in fundamental education.  The classes are disorganized in general and everyone loves to not set up anything until the last minute.  TAs are paid less than most other graduate schools on the mainland where stuff is cheaper.
cons: If you want something done you always have to push for it yourself.  Working for UH Manoa as a TA can be like being back in junior high...you have to play politics.

job_title: Computer Specialist III in Honolulu, HI
pros: My position was secured as "long-term, soft money", which meant I had a job as long as the research grants were funded.  There was a lot of autonomy in choosing which best practice to follow and how to implement it.
cons: Web development within the departments are not coordinated by the University's IT department.  Many benefits would have been seen had they been.

pros: Great campus, diverse students to teach to, interesting learning environment
cons: Departments lack communication, and competition between departments at same university is common here - rather than a cooperative team. Salary is different for grad students in different schools, and varies greatly.  None are competitive or allow for the cost of living or even paying the rent in Hawaii.

job_title: Biomedical Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Honolulu, HI
pros: Lots of opportunity to learn and self develop. Overhead benefits are good (i.e. automatic 10% retirement contribution). Some state of the art facility and technology to utilize. Multi-ethnic workforce is fun to be associated with.
cons: Salary doesn't match up with the cost of living in this state. Local collaborations and expertise of a specific are are very few or not available. Only very few true mentor are available, you will be mostly on your own. Company culture doesn't focus on talent retention. Huge bureaucracy and messy politics.

review_title: Great job opportunity for college students
pros:
- Flexible hours
- Great employee policy, responsibilities as a student are understood and prioritized 
- Get to work within field of interest and fellow students
cons:
- Low maximum hours
- Temporary position with many new position seekers every semester
- Workspace and environment can get loud and crowded. Was difficult to work at times.

job_title: Pacific Island Health Care Project Officer in Honolulu, HI
pros: An Excellent Graduate School in Public Health.  It is situated in the Pacific with access to the Six US Pacific Island Jurisdictions of:  American Samoa, the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia (FSM), Guam, the Commonwealth of the Northern Marianas (CNMI), and Palau.
cons: The availability of qualified / trained medical and public health care workers.

review_title: Your experience will depend on your attitude, location, and personnel around you.
pros: Academic Environment is great work in.  The schedule is good compared to most private employers. The mission of educating and improving the community it is very fulfilling.
cons: As a government agency with its own layers of paperwork and procedures the bureaucracy permeates everything. As with any large organization politicking is prevalent. There are many constituencies who are resistant to chance. This stifles innovation.

review_title: My opinon of UH-Manoa Biology/Zoology TAships
job_title: Lab Teaching Assistant Zoology and Biology Departments in Honolulu, HI
pros: The people are great, I really enjoy teaching the students.
cons: Very low pay for TA's 1,290/mo + tuition waiver. This is so low that graduate students qualify for food stamps. However, by law graduate students are the one group of people that is prohibited from receiving food stamps even if they qualify.

pros: Fortunately they hire new grads. I thought it would be a lot harder to find a position right after graduation.
cons: Not a lot of upper campus parking availability. Also, being a student employee doesn't help you at all if you decide to go full-time afterwards. That experience will not count when they determine your salary. (FYI jobseekers)

review_title: Awesome, easy going, good pay for p/t
pros: I got $13.85/hr for part time computer tech. Very easy going atmosphere and I was left alone most of the time. Very good University to work at.
cons: Behind technology, heck, I clocked in using the old timecard stampers and had to manually enter it in every week. Have to be a student, so no matter how important you are , you are let go after graduation.

review_title: If you like an island lifestyle, you'll like it here
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Honolulu, HI
pros:
Location is great, beautiful campus 
Good place to "work hard and play hard"
Benefits are decent 
Tuition exemption available for faculty
Generally people here are friendly
cons:
Things move slowly here
 departmental politics is a bummer
People just don't like changes, but sort of engrained in the island's culture though
Hard to purchase supplies and equipments from other states and shipping takes a lot longer and more costly 
Difficult to maintain collaboration with other scholars

review_title: I graduated from the University of Hawaii.
pros: I wanted to work at the university of Hawaii because I worked there for more than ten years and it takes care their employees well. In addition to that, it is a safe place to work and the environment is welcoming.
cons: It does not have more parking space for employees. But there is a good bus system in place.

pros: If there is a visionary leader, it's a great place to work
cons: When Administration is "managing" or just being a steward, then nothing gets done and it's either status quo or reduce budget or cut positions

review_title: University of Hawaii at Manoa Part Time Work
pros: Management is very respectful of your academic life allowing you to take time off when needed and to schedule work around school.
cons: Pay is not great and hours are short due to budget cuts but it balances out due to tax benefits.

review_title: Mediocrity is the Standard in Hawaii
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant IV in Honolulu, HI
pros: You probably won't ever have to work -- just say it's someone else's job and that you can't help.  Very little responsibility and accountability.
cons: No one takes responsibility or demonstrates accountability.  Getting to an answer about an important issue is impossible because everyone passes the buck.

review_title: Totally depends on your research group.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Honolulu, HI
pros: In the right research groups, you can participate in excellent research and get excellent exposure for future jobs.  Pay is fair for the area.
cons: The University seems to exploit every loophole possible to save money, at the expense of postdocs and students working there.  Hiring sometimes appears to be very political in nature rather than motivated by the best candidates.

review_title: Disrespectful and Terrible Environment to Work
pros: Since you are working, where you are going to school, it is convenient. The pay grade also starts at $7.75 an hour, instead of minimum wage of $7.25 an hour.
cons: Working with college students can be very frustrated because they sometimes lack motivation and goals. Also, many times they don?t have good work ethics. My boss and supervisors were also not very good at managing the students. Very disrespectful environment.

review_title: UH Manoa is a crossroad for all different cultures and offers enormous opportunities to increase knowledge, & abilities.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Honolulu, HI
pros: Staff are very understanding and flexible.
cons: There are not many funding available for international students pursuing Ph.D. degrees.

job_title: Wildlife Biology Technician in Makawao, HI
pros: Incredible array of projects and experiences with great benefits. Lots of training and development opportunities. Get to work on multiple islands. Great for someone trying to break into conservation work.
cons: Low Salary, beauracracy, not much vertical movement. I ended up going back to school to get a graduate degree since the job seemed to be a dead end.

review_title: UH, good for a short period of time.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Honolulu, HI
pros: You live in Hawaii.  Honolulu is a great city, nice beaches, good waves and plenty of great food.   Could be a lot worse.
cons: Unions.  Nothing gets done.  Low expectations.  Facilities are falling apart. Low operating budget.  Dont expect to meet movers and shakers at this University.  Things are stagnant,

pros: Hawaii state is a great place to work. Both environment and people are very nice there. You will find yourself fitting in easily.
cons: The pace is kind of slow. I think it may be a good point to some people. Since it is distanced from the mainland, it would be hard to participate in activities (e.g. conference) out of the state.

pros: Outstanding faculty, opportunities to help students achieve their goals, teaching assistantships absolutely essential to funding graduate education
cons: Funding is drying up quickly in several departments and opportunities to be hired as a teaching or research assistant are disappearing fast

pros: I was a research assistant its not about the university as much as your research professor. Mine was a little difficult but could have been worse. One thing was you got 4 weeks vacation which was amazing.
cons: Any changes to the system were very hard to make the administrative office was not very helpful and sometimes very condescending.

pros:
On the University of Hawaii at Manoa Campus
Fair compensation for an engineer right out of undergrad
Forward thinking research
cons:
Can be hard to get an interview
Living in Hawaii is expensive

pros: I worked part time for a department chair. He was a great boss in that I had a lot of autonomy as long as I delivered. By Hawaii standards the pay was good.
cons: None, I really enjoyed the job. I think your experience at UH depends a lot on who you work with and for.

review_title: Living in paradise isn't without drawbacks
pros:
Nice environment - living in Hawaii
Aloha spirit - people are nice
Urban campus - and close to beaches
cons:
Static - people are taking their time, and sometimes don't work efficiently
Poor pay compared to other places
Travel to anywhere else costly and time-consuming

review_title: Great place to make some extra money while a student.
pros:
Great opportunities for students to earn some extra money.
Depending on the placement you could be working with amazing people who are understanding of your student situation.
cons: Poor leadership and budgeting on the state level makes it a poor place to get into at this point in time.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Honolulu, HI
pros: As a graduate assistant, my needs were taken into consideration and payment was always on time. Experience likely varies with department
cons: Cons were limited to banking issues (had to open an on-island bank account in order to receive checks), other cons were limited to individual department issues

job_title: Event Planning & Public Relations Officer in Honolulu, HI
pros: A good way to network with a variety of people
cons:
Prehistoric technology makes getting work done much harder than it has to be. They still use typewriters and carbon paper as an everyday office product.
The environment is like working in an office from 1976 - truly!

pros: If one has a BA, BS, MA, MS or PHd, then there are many opportunities at UH.
cons: If one does not have a BA, BS, MA, MS or PHd, then there are no opportunities at UH.

pros: Union backed jobs, decent retirement benefits, tuition waiver for staff members and their spouse.
cons: Closed minded administration that has displayed an unwillingness to listen, compromise or work with staff. Seemingly, no oversite of departments that are left to do as they please, until something critical arrises to grab the administrations attention.

review_title: University of Hawaii - gorgeous, but remote
pros: Good positive people, beautiful campus, decent quality of shared resources, nice pace of life
cons: Insufficient salaries, limited promotion possibilities, limited in terms of collaborations and scientific development, long wait times for orders, limited meeting possibilities, inefficient HR

pros:
Working at UH makes you a state employee

Great benefits if you stay long enough to get them.
cons:
Hostile work environment
Racism
Very little room for growth

pros: Learned basic laboratory upkeep skills and preparation of stock solutions, growth media, upkeep of supplies for labs. Prepared the labs for chemistry and microbiology.
cons: That I had to leave due to my pregnancy.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Honolulu, HI
pros: Learn stuffs and tuition waived. Will gain more research experience while attending school.
cons: It's really hard to maintain the job, and it is depend on the funding situation of the professor you've been working on.

job_title: Institutional Support Specialist in Honolulu, HI
pros: Generous vacation and sick leave.  Decent health benefits.
cons: Majority of positions are tied to a union.  Inequities among salaries.

pros: It's Hawaii... Also there is a great diversity of people.
cons: Poor resources, surfers, poor communication from administrators, no contract, and no one seems to be paid the same way.

pros: UH is a good work environment with good opportunities and benefits.
cons: Your experience at UH most definitely varies depending on the department that you work in. They're all very different from one another.

pros: As a sculpture professor I worked at what I loved doing.  I was one of the lucky ones. Working with students
cons: Politics at the department, endless committee meetings. Colleagues with opposing visions.

pros: Intelligent people to work with
cons: The pay was not that good, especially for living in Hawaii.  Benefits were good as far as options and coverage with insurance but cost too much.

job_title: Invasive Species Biologist in Kahului, HI

review_title: Student research assistant to professor in M.E.
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Honolulu, HI

cons: Pay could have been better. But for a student job, it's fine. It would have been nice to  be pushed more.

pros: Was able to get teaching experience under my belt while studying, flexible schedule
cons: random classroom assignments.. for my 15 person class, i was assigned a lecture hall built for 150

pros: Beautiful environment in Manoa, great team in my department.
cons: University kept me on lecturer pay long after I should have been moved to instructor pay.

pros: flexible student scheduling. hands on learning

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Honolulu, HI

pros: Good work life balance job is not too hard
cons: Management can be difficult, students on campus can be very mean

pros: Located in a diverse and lively environment.
cons: Remuneration for graduate assistants was not particularly exciting given the costs of living in Honolulu.

pros: Lots of vacation time and sick leave.
cons: Can be a little boring. Not a lot of opportunity for advancement.

pros: Works around student schedules, fair pay
cons: No real training, learn skills on the job
